title: 115_hr2831
content: The "Maritime Security Coordination Improvement Act" requires the Secretary to submit updates on the strategic plan for enhancing international supply chain security every three years. Additionally, it includes provisions for the Container Security Initiative. SEC. 3 amends the Container Security Initiative timeline and structure. SEC. 4 addresses cybersecurity at ports. The amendments focus on enhancing cybersecurity in maritime security activities by facilitating information sharing on cybersecurity risks and incidents, establishing working groups to address port-specific cybersecurity risks, and including cybersecurity in vulnerability assessments and security plans. The amendments aim to improve cybersecurity in maritime security activities by addressing cybersecurity risks and incidents, including prevention, management, and response to such threats as defined in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. SEC. 5. Facility inspection intervals are amended to verify the effectiveness of security plans annually and as needed. SEC. 6. Recognition of other countries' trusted shipper programs is addressed in the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006. SEC. 218 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 addresses the recognition of other countries' trusted shipper programs. The Secretary must notify congressional committees before signing an arrangement with a foreign government for mutual recognition of supply chain security practices. The foreign government's supply chain security program must provide comparable security as C-TPAT. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new section on updates to the Maritime Operations Coordination Plan. The Secretary must submit a maritime operations coordination plan every 180 days to specific committees, updating the plan released in July 2011. The plan includes coordination of maritime operations, joint domain awareness efforts, information sharing, and intelligence integration with various stakeholders for maritime security. The Secretary must submit a maritime operations coordination plan every 180 days to specific committees, updating the plan released in July 2011. This includes cooperation and coordination with other federal, state, and local agencies, as well as the private sector, in support of maritime homeland security missions. SEC. 8. EVALUATION OF COAST GUARD DEPLOYABLE SPECIALIZED FORCES. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to specific committees on the state of the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF), including cost analysis, personnel numbers, unit totals, operations conducted, and operations requested. The report will include an analysis of the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF), their operations, and alternative distribution options. Deployable Specialized Force is defined as a unit of the Coast Guard. The term "Deployable Specialized Force" refers to a Coast Guard unit that acts as a quick reaction force for counter-drug, counter-terrorism, and anti-terrorism operations, as well as other maritime threats to the United States. SEC. 9. COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS OF CO-LOCATING DHS ASSETS. The Secretary of Homeland Security must conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets of the Office of Air and Marine Operations with other Department of Homeland Security agencies within 45 miles. Factors to consider include enhanced cooperation, shared maintenance and logistics facilities, joint use of infrastructure, and operational costs. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets within 45 miles. This analysis includes factors such as operational costs, potential moving costs, and infrastructure acquisition costs. A report summarizing the results of the analysis and any planned actions must be submitted to relevant committees within one year of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 10 repeals Sections 70107A and 70116 of title 46, United States Code. SEC. 11 includes conforming and clerical amendments. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by redesignating and striking various sections. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by redesignating and striking various sections, including section 235, 236, 701, and 708. The table of contents is also amended to reflect these changes. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include provisions such as prohibition of transportation security cards for certain felons, long-range vessel tracking, notice of arrival for foreign vessels, enhanced crewmember identification, random searches of containers, work stoppages resolution, threat assessment for port truck drivers, Border Patrol unit for US Virgin Islands, and Center of Excellence for Maritime Domain Awareness. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include new items related to supply chain security cooperation, trucking security, air and marine operations, vessel phaseout, Coast Guard property, methamphetamine control, and disaster safety. Amendments also involve changes in title 46 regarding vessel tracking and crew identification.
